content.description:
Progenuitprogigno, -ere, -genui: to give birth to1 pedibus celerem et pernicibuspernix, -icis, adj. = celer, -eris, -ere alis, 
monstrum horrendum, ingens, cui quot sunt corpore plumaepluma, -ae, f.: feather, 
tot vigilesvigil, -ilis, adj.: wakeful oculi subtersubter, adv.: underneath (mirabile dictu), 
tot linguae, totidemtotidem, adj.: (just) as many ora sonant, tot subrigit subrigo, -ere = tollo, -ereaures.
 1:Supply Terra as the subject of Progenuit and Famam as its direct object.↩
content.question: Which of the following features of the epic genre does the passage best illustrate?

choices.label: A hero is helped by divine interventions.
The narrative of an epic plunges the reader in medias res.
A hero must descend to the Underworld to complete his or her quest.
The narrative of an epic is moved forward by the gods or personified forces.

content.answer: The narrative of an epic is moved forward by the gods or personified forces.

unit.text: 5: Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 4, 6, 7, 11, and 12

skill.text: 2.A: Describe features and functions of stylistic elements in Latin texts.
